[[Image:Paterson strike leaders.jpg|thumb|right|300px|1913 photo of [[Paterson silk strike of 1913|Paterson silk strike]] leaders [[Patrick Quinlan (activist)|Patrick Quinlan]], [[Carlo Tresca]], [[Elizabeth Gurley Flynn]], [[Adolph Lessig]], and Haywood]]
[[Image:Paterson strike leaders.jpg|thumb|right|300px|1913 photo of [[Paterson silk strike of 1913|Paterson silk strike]] leaders [[Patrick Quinlan (activist)|Patrick Quinlan]], [[Carlo Tresca]], [[Elizabeth Gurley Flynn]], [[Adolph Lessig]], and Haywood]]
In 1913, Haywood was involved in the [[Paterson silk strike of 1913|Paterson silk strike]]. Haywood and approximately 1,850 strikers were arrested during the course of the strike.<ref>The Samuel Gompers Papers.</ref> Despite the long holdout and fundraising efforts, the strike ended in failure on [[July 28]], [[1913]].
In 1913, Haywood was involved in the [[Paterson silk strike of 1913|Paterson silk strike]]. Haywood and approximately 1,850 strikers were arrested during the course of the strike.<ref>The Samuel Gompers Papers.</ref> Despite the long holdout and fundraising efforts, the strike ended in failure on [[July 28]], [[1913]].
Line 76: Line 75:
But Haywood's industrial unionism was much broader than formulating a more effective method of conducting strikes. Haywood grew up a part of the [[Working class|working class]], and his respect for working people was genuine. He was quickly angered by the arrogance of employers "who had never ... spoken to a workingman except to give orders."<Ref>Carlson, 60.</Ref>
But Haywood's industrial unionism was much broader than formulating a more effective method of conducting strikes. Haywood grew up a part of the [[Working class|working class]], and his respect for working people was genuine. He was quickly angered by the arrogance of employers "who had never ... spoken to a workingman except to give orders."<Ref>Carlson, 60.</Ref>
  +
[[Image:Bill_haywood_iww_convention.jpg|thumb|left|200|Haywood at a convention in Chicago (1917)]]
Having met Debs during his WFM days, Haywood had also become interested in the former railway leader's new passion, socialism. Haywood subscribed to the belief, and formulated as a new motto for the WFM, that:
